## Introduction

Consider the example:

(@ex000355) [ذَهَابُ زَيْدٍ]{.ar}  
    [Zayd's going]{.trans}  

The noun
[ذَهَاب]{.ar}
[going]{.trans}
is the [maSdar]{.trn2} of the verb
[ذَهَبَ يَذْهَبُ]{.ar}
[to go]{.trans}.

Like the verb
[ذَهَبَ يَذْهَبُ]{.ar},
the [maSdar]{.trn2}
[ذَهَاب]{.ar}
signifies the action
of going.
But unlike the verb,
the [maSdar]{.trn2} does not include tense.
So it doesn't say when the action of going happened or will happen.

The [maSdar]{.trn2} 
is classified as a primitive noun,
not a deverbal noun.
In other words, in terms of grammatical theory,
it is not considered to be derived from the verb.
(Rather, the verb is considered to be derived from the [maSdar]{.trn2}.)


Also the [maSdar]{.trn2} is not a adjectival noun.
Technically,
this would put it in the category of entity nouns.
But because the [maSdar]{.trn2} signifies the action of a verb, and not an actual entity,
it is an abstract entity noun, not a concrete entity noun.
In fact, we will treat it in a category of its own.
We will see, if Allāh wills,
that the [maSdar]{.trn2} can cross over to a concrete entity noun and then refer to an entity.

But because the [maSdar]{.trn2} is a special noun that signifies the action of a verb, and not really an entity,

## The [maSdar]{.trn2} as a verb-like governor in an annexation

As a noun which is related to a verb, a [maSdar]{.trn2} can govern in a verb-like manner.
Let's start with a sentence which has a verb:

(@ex000356) [يسرني أن تأتي]{.ar}
<!--
(@ex000357) [أرجو أن يعتدلَ الجو]{.ar}
    [[nahw_wadih 1/54](https://shamela.ws/book/10018/48)]{.citex}  
    [I hope that the weather becomes moderate]{.trans}  
-->


[أَنْ]{.ar} in the above example is that [maSdar]{.trn2}i [أَنْ]{.ar}.
This means that,
as we learned in chapter\ (ref),
it and its following verb
can be interpreted as a [maSdar]{.trn2} construction, thus:

<!--
(@ex000358) [أرجو اعتدال الجو]{.ar}
    [I hope [for] the weather's moderateness]{.trans}  
-->
(@ex000359) [يسرني إتيانك]{.ar}

We also learned that this interpretation of the
[maSdar]{.trn2}i [أَنْ]{.ar} clause
in example () above
allows us to grammatically model the [أَنْ]{.ar} clause as one structural element.
In example () above the [maSdar]{.trn2} construction
[إتيانك]{.ar} is  modeled as the doer of the verb [يسر]{.ar}.


<!--
([اعتدال]{.ar} in example () above is in the a-state as the doee of the verb [أرجو]{.ar}.)
-->

But example () is also a legitimate sentence in its own right.
The [maSdar]{.trn2} [إتيان]{.ar} signifies the occurrence of the verb
[أتى يأتي]{.ar}.
But unlike the verb, it does not indicate tense.
If we had started with a perfect verb, for example:

(@ex000360) [يسرني أن أتيت]{.ar}

then it would have the same modeled [maSdar]{.trn2}:

(@ex000361) [يسرني إتيانك]{.ar}

In order to add tense to sentence with [maSdar]{.trn2},
we would have to use other means, for example, an adverb:

(@ex000362) [يسرني إتيانك غدا]{.ar}

(@ex000363) [يسرني إتيانك أمس]{.ar}

In example () above,
the
[maSdar]{.trn2} [إتيان]{.ar}
is a annexe noun in an annexation.
Syntactically,
the pronoun [ك]{.ar}
is in the i-state as the base noun in the annexation,
but semantically, it is considered the doer of the.
[maSdar]{.trn2} [إتيان]{.ar}.

In example () above
the verb
[تأتي]{.ar}
was used without a direct doee.
Let's see what happens when we add a direct doee.
For example:

(@ex000364) [يسرني أن تأتيني]{.ar}

In example () above,
the pronoun [ي]{.ar} [me]{.ar}
is the direct doee of the verb
[تأتي]{.ar}.
If we model the [أَنْ]{.ar} clause in example () above as a [maSdar]{.trn2} construction,
then we will get:

(@ex000365) [يسرني إتيانك إِيَّايَ]{.ar}

Now, the pronoun [ك]{.ar} [your]{.trans} is again the syntactic base noun and the semantic doer
of the
[maSdar]{.trn2} [إتيان]{.ar}.
But the [maSdar]{.trn2} now also has a direct doee
[إِيَايَ]{.ar} in the a-state.

#### The [maSdar]{.trn2} in an annexation governing a u-state doer {.unnumbered}

Here is another example of a [maSdar]{.trn2} governing a semantic
doer and a direct doee:

(@ex000366) [عَجِبْتُ مِنْ شُرْبِ زَيْدٍ الْعَسَلَ]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 3/102](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/780)]{.citex}  

But this is not the only word order which is possible.
We can flip the order of the doer and the direct doee, thus:

(@ex000367) [عَجِبْتُ مِنْ شُرْبِ الْعَسَلِ زَيْدٌ]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 3/102](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/780)]{.citex}  

Now the semantic direct doee 
[العسل]{.ar}
is the base noun in the i-state
and the doer [زيد]{.ar} is in the u-state.

This word order of
the direct doee's being the base noun and the doer occurring after it in the u-state
([شُرْبِ الْعَسَلِ زَيْدٌ]{.ar})
is not as usual as the usual word order
([شُرْبِ الْعَسَلِ زَيْدٌ]{.ar}).^[Wright 2/59B]
Nevertheless, it is common enough.^[[[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 3/103](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/781#p1)]

#### The [maSdar]{.trn2} in an annexation governing only a direct doee without a doer {.unnumbered}

The doer of the [maSdar]{.trn2} need not be mentioned.
In this case, the [maSdar]{.trn2} is a annexe noun noun to its sementic direct doee directly.
For example:

(@ex000368) [مَنَعَهُمْ مِنْ قَوْلِ الْحَقِّ]{.ar}
    [Wright 2/57C]{.citex}  
    [He hindered them from saying the truth.]{.trans}  

Sometimes, context would be needed to tell whether the base noun is the semantic doer or the sementic direct doee.
For example:

(@ex000369) [عجبت من ضرب زيد]{.ar}
    [[[التذييل والتكميل لأبي حيان]{.ar} 11/70](https://shamela.ws/book/17116/3605#p1)]{.citex}  

In example () above,
[زيد]{.ar} may either have been the person who did the beating or the person who was beaten.^[[[التذييل والتكميل لأبي حيان]{.ar} 11/70](https://shamela.ws/book/17116/3605#p1)]
Context would be needed to disambiguate.

#### The [maSdar]{.trn2} governing a deputy doer {.unnumbered}

Just like the [maSdar]{.trn2} can govern a doer in the u-state
it can similarly govern a deputy doer.
For example:

(@ex000370) [سَرَّنِي إِعْطَاءُ الدَّنَانِيرِ **الْفَقِيرُ**]{.ar}
    [[[شرح التسهيل لابن مالك]{.ar} 3/109](https://shamela.ws/book/13257/925)]{.citex}  
    [The giving of the [dInAr]{.trn2}s to the poor-one made me happy.]{.trans}  

#### The [maSdar]{.trn2} governing multiple direct doees {.unnumbered}

The [maSdar]{.trn2} can govern multiple direct doees just like its verb.
For example:

(@ex000371) [عَرَفْتُ إِعْطَاءَكَ الْفَقِيرَ دِرْهَمًا]{.ar}
    [[[شرح التسهيل لابن مالك]{.ar} 3/109](https://shamela.ws/book/13257/925)]{.citex}  

(@ex000372) [عَرَفْتُ إِعْلَامَكَ خَالِدًا جَعْفَرًا مُقِيمًا]{.ar}
    [[[شرح التسهيل لابن مالك]{.ar} 3/109](https://shamela.ws/book/13257/925)]{.citex}  

#### The [maSdar]{.trn2} in a annexation to an adverb of time/place

The adverb of time/place, like a ;mafulb, is considered a doee.
As such, it can be a base noun to a governing [maSdar]{.trn2}.
Any doer and/or direct doees will then occur after it in their respective syntactic states.
For example:

(@ex000373) [عَجِبْتُ مِنْ ضَرْبِ **اليَوْمِ** زَيْدٌ عَمْرًا]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 3/103](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/781#p1)]{.citex}  
    [I wondered at today's beating [by] Zayd [to] [#eamr]{.trn2}]{.trans}  

#### A attribute to a governing [maSdar]{.trn2} in an annexation {.unnumbered}

A [maSdar]{.trn2} which is governing a governee (like a doer or a direct doee)
can be described by a attribute,
but that attribute should occur after the [maSdar]{.trn2}'s governees.^[[[شرح التسهيل لابن مالك]{.ar} 3/108](https://shamela.ws/book/13257/924#p1); [النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 2/188]
For example,
we should not say:

(@ex000374) ✗ [عرفت سوقك **العنيف** الإبل]{.ar}
    [[[شرح التسهيل لابن مالك]{.ar} 3/108](https://shamela.ws/book/13257/924#p1)]{.citex}  
    [I knew your harsh driving of the camels]{.trans}  

We should say instead:

(@ex000375) [عرفت سوقك الإبل **العنيف**]{.ar}

#### A attribute to the governee of a [maSdar]{.trn2} in an annexation {.unnumbered}

When the [maSdar]{.trn2} is governing a doer or a direct doee in an annexation,
and that governee is to be described by a attribute,
then the attribute may,
optionally,
be either in the i-state,
or in the u-state for the doer and the a-state for the direct doee.^[[النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 2/189; [[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 3/104--105](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/782#p1); Wright 2/59C]
So we can say:

(@ex000376) [عجبت من شرب زيد الظريف والظريف]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 3/104](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/782#p1)]{.citex}  

(@ex000377) [عَجِبْتُ مِنْ أَكْلِ الطَّعَامِ الْحَارِّ/الْحَارَّ زَيْدٌ]{.ar}
    [[النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 2/189]{.citex}  
    [I wondered at the eating of the hot food [by] Zayd]{.trans}  

#### A conjunction to the governee of a [maSdar]{.trn2} in an annexation {.unnumbered}

When the [maSdar]{.trn2} is governing a doer or a direct doee in an annexation,
and that governee is followed by a conjunction and post-conjunction,
then the post-conjunction may,
optionally,
be either in the i-state,
or in the u-state for the doer and the a-state for the direct doee.^[[النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 2/189; Wright 2/57D-58A]
So we can say:

(@ex000378) [سَاءَنِي إِهْمَالُ سَعِيدٍ وَخَالِدٍ/خَالِدٌ]{.ar}
    [[النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 2/189]{.citex}  

(@ex000379) [كَرِهْتُ أَكْلَ الْخُبْزِ وَاللَّحْمِ/اللَّحْمَ]{.ar}
    [Wright 2/58A]{.citex}  
    [I disliked eating the bread and the meat.]{.trans}  

(@ex000380) [سَاءَنِي ضَرْبُ خَالِدٍ وَسَعِيدٍ/سَعِيدًا خَلِيلٌ]{.ar}
    [[النحو العربي: أحكام ومعان]{.ar} 2/189]{.citex}  

## The [tanwIn]{.trn2}ed [maSdar]{.trn2} as a verb-like governor

In section\ (ref) above,
we have seen how the [maSdar]{.trn2} governing in an annexation.
However, an annexation is not the only form in which a [maSdar]{.trn2} can govern in a verb-like manner.
A [maSdar]{.trn2} can also govern when it is [tanwIn]{.trn2}ed.
For example:

(@masdar_darbin_zaydan) [عَجِبتُ مِن ضَرْبٍ زيدا]{.ar}
    [[[كتاب سيبويه]{.ar} 1/189](https://shamela.ws/book/23018/187); [[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 3/94](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/772#p1)]{.citex}

(@masdar_darbin_zaydan_bakrun) [عجبتُ مِن ضَرْبٍ زيداً بكرٌ]{.ar}
    [[[كتاب سيبويه]{.ar} 1/189](https://shamela.ws/book/23018/187)]{.citex}

(@masdar_darbin_zaydun_3amran) [عَجِبْتُ مِنْ ضَرْبٍ زَيْدٌ عَمْرًا]{.ar}
    [modified from [[كتاب سيبويه]{.ar} 1/189](https://shamela.ws/book/23018/187); Wright 2/59A]{.citex}

(@ex000381) [أَوۡ إِطۡعَـٰمࣱ فِی یَوۡمࣲ ذِی مَسۡغَبَةࣲ ۝١٤ یَتِیمࣰا ذَا مَقۡرَبَةٍ ۝١٥]{.quran}
    [[[سورة البلد]{.ar} 90:14-15](https://quran.com/90/14-15), cited by [[شرح التسهيل لابن مالك]{.ar} 3/115](https://shamela.ws/book/13257/931#p1)]{.citex}  
    [Or feeding on a day of severe hunger An orphan of near relationship]{.trans}  

(@ex000382) [بضرب بالسيوف رؤوس قوم]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 3/94](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/772#p1); Wright 2/57C]{.citex}  
    [by striking, with the swords, the heads of a people]{.trans}  


The [tanwIn]{.trn2}ed [maSdar]{.trn2} governing a doer and a direct doee is comparatively rarer
than the [maSdar]{.trn2} governing in a annexation.^[Wright 2/59B; [[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 3/94](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/772#p1)]
Some grammarians mandate that when a [tanwIn]{.trn2}ed [maSdar]{.trn2} is a governor then its doer should not be mentioned after it.^[[[التذييل والتكميل لأبي حيان]{.ar} 11/75](https://shamela.ws/book/17116/3610)]
So they would allow example
(@masdar_darbin_zaydan) above but not examples (@masdar_darbin_zaydan_bakrun) and (@masdar_darbin_zaydun_3amran).

## The [maSdar]{.trn2} prefixed by [ال]{.ar} as a verb-like governor

In addition to the [maSdar]{.trn2} governing in an annexation and when [tanwIn]{.trn2}ed,
the [maSdar]{.trn2} can also govern when it is prefixed by [ال]{.ar}.
This is the rarest out of the three formations.^[[[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 3/94](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/772#p1)]

(@ex000383) [عجبت من الضرب زيدا]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 3/94](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/772#p1)]{.citex}  

(@ex000384) [ضَعِيفُ النِّكَايَةِ أَعْدَاءَهُ]{.ar}
    [[[شرح التسهيل لابن مالك]{.ar} 3/116](https://shamela.ws/book/13257/932#p1); Wright 2/57D]{.citex}  
    [weak in harming his enemies]{.trans}

(@ex000385) [فلم أنكُلْ عن الضَّرْبِ مسْمِعا]{.ar}
    [[[شرح التسهيل لابن مالك]{.ar} 3/116](https://shamela.ws/book/13257/932#p1); Wright 2/57D]{.citex}  
    [and I did not desist from beating [#mismae]{.trn2}]{.trans}  

## The [maSdar]{.trn2} as a verb-like governor compared to the doer participle

We have already seen, in chapter\ (ref),
that the doer participle is also
a noun that is related to a verb, and that can govern in a verb-like manner.
But the [maSdar]{.trn2} and the doer participle are different in how they govern a doer and a direct doee.

Firstly, the [maSdar]{.trn2} is a primitive noun.
So it does not govern a
latent doer pronoun.
When the [maSdar]{.trn2} is governing a direct doee without a doer
as in example ()
[مَنَعَهُمْ مِنْ قَوْلِ الْحَقِّ]{.ar}
then, no latent doer pronoun is virtual modeled.

Secondly, when the [maSdar]{.trn2} is governing in an annexation,
(for example
[عَجِبْتُ مِنْ ضَرْبِ زَيْدٍ عَمْرًا]{.ar})
then this annexation is real, not superficial.^[[شرح ألفية ابن مالك للحازمي]{.ar} 71/9]
However, when the doer participle is governing in an annexation, then the annexation is superficial (see section\ (ref)).

Thirdly, the doer participle not prefixed by [ال]{.ar} only governs in a verb-like manner
when it has an imperfective meaning.
The [maSdar]{.trn2} on the other hand can govern for both a perfective and imperfective meaning.
For example:

(@ex000386) [عجبت من ضربك زيدا أمس/غدا/الآن]{.ar}
    [modified from [[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 3/94](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/772#p1)]{.citex}  

The [maSdar]{.trn2} as a verb-like governor
does have one similarity to the governing doer participle.
And that is that both their doers are not the
structure-starter of a new sentence.
So, for example, in the sentence:

(@ex000387) [عَجِبْتُ مِنْ شُرْبِ الْعَسَلِ زَيْدٌ]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 3/102](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/780)]{.citex}  


the doer [زَيْد]{.ar} does not form an inner sentence with the [maSdar]{.trn2} [شُرْب]{.ar}.
Rather, the [maSdar]{.trn2}
[شُرْب]{.ar},
as a single-word element, is in the i-state, governed by the preposition [مِنْ]{.ar}.

An exception to the doer of a [maSdar]{.trn2} not being a structure-starter,
and also to the [maSdar]{.trn2} not governing a latent doer pronoun,
is when the [maSdar]{.trn2} occurs as the deputy to a verb.
For example:

(@ex000388) [ضربا زيدا]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 3/93](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/771)]{.citex}  
    [Hit Zayd!]{.trans}  

The [maSdar]{.trn2} as a deputy to a verb will be covered in more detail in section\ (mmutlaq), if Allāh wills.

## The entity noun→[maSdar]{.trn2}

The entity noun→[maSdar]{.trn2} is a concrete entity noun that crosses over to be used like a [maSdar]{.trn2}.
Examples:

| entity noun→[maSdar]{.trn2} | verb | actual [maSdar]{.trn2} |
|:----|:-----|:--|
|[سَلَام]{.ar} [peace]{.trans}  |[سَلَّمَ يُسَلِّمُ]{.ar}  [to say]{.trans} [السَّلَامُ عَلَيْكُمْ]{.ar} ([عَلَى]{.ar} to s.o.) |[تَسْلِيم]{.ar} |
|[عَطَاء]{.ar} [a gift]{.trans}   |[أَعْطَى يُعْطِي]{.ar} [to give]{.trans} |[إِعْطَاء]{.ar} |
|[كَلَام]{.ar} [a speech]{.trans} |[كَلَّمَ يُكَلِّمُ]{.ar}  [to speak]{.trans} [(to]{.trans} [ه]{.ar} [s.o.)]{.trans} |[تَكْلِيم]{.ar} |
|[كَلَام]{.ar} [a speech]{.trans} |[تَكَلَّمَ يَتَكَلَّمُ]{.ar}  [to speak]{.trans} |[تَكَلُّم]{.ar} |
|[قُبْلَة]{.ar} [a kiss]{.trans} |[قَبَّلَ يُقَبِّلُ]{.ar}  [to kiss (]{.trans} [ه]{.ar} [s.o.)]{.trans}|[تَقْبِيل]{.ar} |
|[عَذَاب]{.ar} [a punishment]{.trans} |[عَذَّبَ يُعَذِّبُ]{.ar}  [to punish ([ه]{.ar} s.o.)]{.trans}|[تَعْذِيب]{.ar} |
|[حِمْل]{.ar} [a load]{.trans} |[حَمَلَ يَحْمِلُ]{.ar}  [to carry ([هـ]{.ar} s.th.)]{.trans}|[حَمْل]{.ar} |
|[عِشْرَة]{.ar} [association]{.trans} |[عَاشَرَ يُعَاشِرُ]{.ar}  [to consort (with [ه]{.ar} s.o.)]{.trans}|[مُعَاشَرَة]{.ar} |

The entity noun→[maSdar]{.trn2} originally signifies the meaning of a concrete entity noun.^[[[معاني النحو]{.ar} 3/164--167](https://shamela.ws/book/17801/889)]
So, for example
the [maSdar]{.trn2} [تَكْلِيم]{.ar} signifies the action of speaking to someone,
and the entity noun→[maSdar]{.trn2} [كَلَام]{.ar} signifies the concrete entity noun [speech]{.trans}.
But the entity noun→[maSdar]{.trn2}, once it crosses over to a [maSdar]{.trn2},
can signify the action of the verb, just like the actual [maSdar]{.trn2}.
As such, it can even govern in a verb-like manner.^[[[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 3/101](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/779#p1)]
So we can say:

(@ex000389) [**بِعِشْرَتِكَ الْكِرَامَ** تُعَدُّ مِنْهُمْ]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 3/100](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/778#p1)]{.citex}  
    [By your associating with the generous-ones you will be reckoned [as one] amongst them.]{.trans}  
    ([الْكِرَام]{.ar} is in the a-state as the direct doee of the entity noun→[maSdar]{.trn2} [عِشْرَة]{.ar}.)  

(@ex000390) [وَبَعْدَ عَطَائِكَ الْمِائَةَ]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن عقيل على الألفية]{.ar} 3/99](https://shamela.ws/book/9904/777#p1)]{.citex}  
    [And after your giving of the one hundred (camels)]{.trans}  
    ([الْمِائَة]{.ar} is in the a-state as the direct doee of the entity noun→[maSdar]{.trn2} [عَطَاء]{.ar}.)  

(@ex000391) [قَالُوا كَلَامُكَ هِنْدًا وَهِيَ مُصْغِيَةٌ يَشْفِيكَ]{.ar}
    [[[حاشية الصبان على شرح الأشمونى لألفية ابن مالك]{.ar} 2/435](https://shamela.ws/book/11539/865)]{.citex}  
    [They said "Your speaking to Hind while she is giving ear will cure you."]{.trans}  
    ([هِنْد]{.ar} is in the a-state as the direct doee of the entity noun→[maSdar]{.trn2} [كَلَام]{.ar}.)  
    
## The [maSdar]{.trn2}→entity noun

Just like the entity noun→[maSdar]{.trn2} crosses over from a entity noun to a [maSdar]{.trn2},
the [maSdar]{.trn2}→entity noun
crosses over form a [maSdar]{.trn2} to a entity noun.
Here are some examples^[mostly taken from [[دراسات في النحو للزعبلاوي]{.ar} 129ff](https://shamela.ws/book/2120/129)]

| [maSdar]{.trn2}→entity noun | plural | verb |
|:----|:-|:----|
|[عِلْم]{.ar} [a science]{.trans}   |[عُلُوم]{.ar} |[عَلِمَ يَعْلَمُ]{.ar}  [to know]{.trans} |
|[عَقْل]{.ar} [an intellect]{.trans} |[عُقُول]{.ar} |[عَقَلَ يَعْقِلُ]{.ar}  [to make sense ([هـ]{.ar} of s.th.)]{.trans} |
|[عَمَل]{.ar} [a deed]{.trans} |[أَعْمَال]{.ar} |[عَمِلَ يَعْمَلُ]{.ar}  [to work]{.trans} |
|[ظَنّ]{.ar} [a conjecture]{.trans} |[ظُنُون]{.ar} |[ظَنَّ يَظُنُّ]{.ar}  [to conjecture]{.trans} |
|[صَوْت]{.ar} [a sound]{.trans} |[أَصْوَات]{.ar} |[صَاتَ يَصُوتُ]{.ar}  [to make a sound]{.trans} |
|[مَعِيشَة]{.ar} [a livelihood]{.trans} |[مَعَايِش]{.ar} |[عَاشَ يَعِيشُ]{.ar}  [to live]{.trans} |
|[عَقْد]{.ar} [a contract]{.trans} |[عُقُود]{.ar} |[عَقَدَ يَعْقِدُ]{.ar}  [to enter into a contract]{.trans} |
|[وَعْد]{.ar} [a promise]{.trans} |[وُعُود]{.ar} |[وَعَدَ يَعِدُ]{.ar}  [to promise]{.trans} |
|[عِدَة]{.ar} [a promise]{.trans} |[عِدَات]{.ar} |[وَعَدَ يَعِدُ]{.ar}  [to promise]{.trans} |
|[مَوْعِد/مَوْعِدَة]{.ar} [a promise]{.trans} |[مَوَاعِد]{.ar} |[وَعَدَ يَعِدُ]{.ar}  [to promise]{.trans} |
|[تَضْعِيف]{.ar} [a double]{.trans} |[تَضَاعِيف]{.ar} |[ضَعَّفَ يُضَعِّفُ]{.ar}  [to double ([هـ]{.ar} s.th.)]{.trans} |
|[تَجْرِبَة]{.ar} [a trial, experiment]{.trans} |[تَجَارِب]{.ar} |[جَرَّبَ يُجَرِّبُ]{.ar}  [to try ([ه، هـ]{.ar} s.o., s.th.)]{.trans} |


As you can see,
once
a [maSdar]{.trn2} crosses over to a entity noun,
it can, and often does, have a plural.

### Plurals of [maSdar]{.trn2}→entity nouns

As you can see, most of the
[maSdar]{.trn2}→entity nouns
in the table above are from stem\ 1 verbs.
There are relatively fewer from stem\ 2 verbs.
Most form broken plurals.
All the plurals above
are amongst those that are attested usage from Classical Arabic.

Most
[maSdar]{.trn2}s
are not attested to have plurals from Classical Arabic.
For example, perhaps we may not find the [maSdar]{.trn2} [اسْتِعْمَال]{.ar}
(from the verb [اسْتَعْمَلَ يَسْتَعْمِلُ]{.ar})
to have the its plural as attested usage
in Classical Arabic.
This has led some grammarians to restrict plurals of [maSdar]{.trn2}s to only those recorded from attested usage.^[[جمع المصدر وأحكامه لحياني]{.ar} 96; [[دراسات في النحو للزعبلاوي]{.ar} 138](https://shamela.ws/book/2120/138)]

After the era of native Classical Arabic,
when [sca]{.smallcaps}
became the language of science and literature,
new terms and meanings were added to the language and used with their technical meanings.
Many of these new terms are
[maSdar]{.trn2}→entity nouns
and they are often from higher stem verbs.
Here are some examples^[mostly taken from [[دراسات في النحو للزعبلاوي]{.ar} 141--142](https://shamela.ws/book/2120/141), [جمع المصدر وأحكامه لحياني]{.ar} 99--100]

| [maSdar]{.trn2}→entity noun | plural | verb |
|:----|:-|:----|
|[اسْتِعْمَال]{.ar} [a use]{.trans}   |[اسْتِعْمَالَات]{.ar} |[اسْتَعْمَلَ يَسْتَعْمِلُ]{.ar}  [to use ([هـ]{.ar} s.th.)]{.trans} |
|[احْتِمَال]{.ar} [a possible interpretation]{.trans}   |[احْتِمَالَات]{.ar} |[احْتَمَلَ يَحْتَمِلُ]{.ar}  [to bear a meaning (of a text)]{.trans} |
|[اعْتِقَاد]{.ar} [a creed]{.trans}   |[اعْتِقَادَات]{.ar} |[اعْتَقَدَ يَعْتَقِدُ]{.ar}  [to believe (a creed)]{.trans} |
|[إِشْكَال]{.ar} [a textual difficulty]{.trans}   |[إِشْكَالَات]{.ar} |[أَشْكَلَ يُشْكِلُ]{.ar}  [to be difficult (of a text)]{.trans} |
|[تَعْرِيف]{.ar} [a definition]{.trans}   |[تَعْرِيفَات]{.ar} |[عَرَّفَ يُعَرِّفُ]{.ar}  [to define ([هـ]{.ar} s.th.)]{.trans} |
|[تَفْسِير]{.ar} [an explanation]{.trans}   |[تَفَاسِير]{.ar} |[فَسَّرَ يُفَسِّرُ]{.ar}  [to explain ([هـ]{.ar} s.th.)]{.trans} |
|[حَذْف]{.ar} [a deletion]{.trans} | [حُذُوف]{.ar} | [حَذَفَ يَحْذِفُ]{.ar} [to delete ([هـ]{.ar} s.th.)]{.trans} |

Because of the need to pluralize technical terms, some scholars have permitted that
new [maSdar]{.trn2}→entity nouns can be pluralized without restriction.^[[[دراسات في النحو للزعبلاوي]{.ar} 129ff](https://shamela.ws/book/2120/129)]

As you can see, many of these
[maSdar]{.trn2}→entity nouns
are from higher stem verbs.
Since, broken plurals are not easily formed from words with many letters, the [At]{.trn} plural is preferred for these
[maSdar]{.trn2}→entity nouns.
The [maSdar]{.trn2} pattern [تَفْعِيل]{.ar} of stem\ 2 [فَعَّلَ]{.ar} verbs can easily form a plural on the pattern [تَفَاعِيل]{.ar},
but even for
new [maSdar]{.trn2}→entity nouns
on this pattern,
the [At]{.trn} plural often tends to be in current usage.

Remember, however, from section\ (ref), that
there are conditions that should be satisfied in order for a word
to have a [At]{.trn} plural.
So if a
[maSdar]{.trn2}→entity noun
does not end with [ة]{.ar} and has fewer than five letters than we may prefer to form a broken plural than a [At]{.trn} plural.
Nevertheless the [At]{.trn} plural may be more common in actual usage.
For example:
[بَيَان]{.ar} [a statement]{.trans}, plural: [أَبْيِنَة]{.ar}, [بَيَانَات]{.ar}.
^[[[دراسات في النحو للزعبلاوي]{.ar} 147--151](https://shamela.ws/book/2120/147)]

### The ability of [maSdar]{.trn2}→entity nouns to govern in a verb-like manner

The default for concrete entity nouns is that they will not govern in a verb-like manner.
But
a [maSdar]{.trn2}→entity noun,
<!--
only form plurals once they
-->
even though it
has crossed over to a entity noun,
its [maSdar]{.trn2} origin
retains some influence.
Because of this,
we do sometimes find
<!--
a plural of
-->
a [maSdar]{.trn2}→entity noun
governing in a verb-like manner.
This is most apparently visible in the plural of a 
[maSdar]{.trn2}→entity noun.
For example:

(@ex000392) [وجرّبوه فما زادتْ **تجاربُهم أبا** قدامةَ إلّا الحزمَ والفَنَعا]{.ar}
    [[[شرح التسهيل لابن مالك]{.ar} 107](https://shamela.ws/book/13257/923#p1)]{.citex}  
    [And they tried him, but their tryings of [#abU #qudAmah]{.trn2} did not increase but [his] resolve and contentment]{.trans}  
    (The plural [maSdar]{.trn2}→entity noun [تَجَارِب]{.ar} is governing  [أَبا]{.ar} in the a-state as a direct doee.)  

## The [maSdar]{.trn2}→adjectival noun

A
[maSdar]{.trn2}→adjectival noun
is a [maSdar]{.trn2} that crosses over to be used like a adjectival noun.
For example,
the [maSdar]{.trn2}
[عَدْل]{.ar}
of the verb
[عَدَلَ يَعْدِلُ]{.ar}
[to act justly]{.trans}
is used as a adjectival noun to mean [just]{.trans}.
Similarly,
the [maSdar]{.trn2}
[رِضًى]{.ar}
of the verb
[رَضِيَ يَرْضَى]{.ar}
[to be pleased]{.trans}
is used as a adjectival noun to mean [pleasing]{.trans}.
Here is an example sentence:

(@ex000393) [هذا رجلٌ عدلٌ]{.ar}
    [[[شرح ابن يعيش على المفصل]{.ar} 2/238](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/688)]{.citex}  
    [This is a just man.]{.trans}

When a [maSdar]{.trn2} is used as a adjectival noun,
then, normally, it is not feminized, dualized or pluralized, regardless of the number or gender of the described noun.
So we will say:

(@ex000394) [مررت برجل عدل أو رضي]{.ar}
    [[[شرح الفارضي على ألفية ابن مالك]{.ar} 3/176](https://shamela.ws/book/174/1302)]{.citex}  

(@ex000395) [مررت بامرأتين رضي]{.ar}
    [[[شرح الفارضي على ألفية ابن مالك]{.ar} 3/176](https://shamela.ws/book/174/1302)]{.citex}  

(@ex000396) [مررت برجلين عدل]{.ar}
    [[[شرح الفارضي على ألفية ابن مالك]{.ar} 3/176](https://shamela.ws/book/174/1302)]{.citex}  

(@ex000397) [مررت برجال عدل]{.ar}
    [[[شرح الفارضي على ألفية ابن مالك]{.ar} 3/176](https://shamela.ws/book/174/1302)]{.citex}  

Sometimes, a particular
[maSdar]{.trn2} is used very often as a adjectival noun.
Then, exceptionally, it is feminized and pluralized.^[[[شرح ابن يعيش على المفصل]{.ar} 2/238](https://shamela.ws/book/13301/688)]
Such is the case with the [maSdar]{.trn2}→adjectival noun [عَدْل]{.ar}.
So we can (optionally) say:

(@ex000398) [امرأة عدلة]{.ar}
    [[[شرح الفارضي على ألفية ابن مالك]{.ar} 3/176](https://shamela.ws/book/174/1302)]{.citex}  

(@ex000399) [نساء عدلات]{.ar}
    [[[شرح الفارضي على ألفية ابن مالك]{.ar} 3/176](https://shamela.ws/book/174/1302)]{.citex}  

(@ex000400) [قوم عدول]{.ar}
    [[[شرح الفارضي على ألفية ابن مالك]{.ar} 3/176](https://shamela.ws/book/174/1302)]{.citex}  

Also, excepted from the restriction of not being pluralized
is a [maSdar]{.trn2}→adjectival noun which ends with a [ة]{.ar}.
This is readily pluralized with a [At]{.trn} plural.
For example [ثِقَة]{.ar} [trustworthy]{.trans}.
So we can say:

(@ex000401) [رِجَالٌ ثِقَاتٌ]{.ar}  
    [trustworthy men]{.trans}  

## The [maSdar]{.trn2} used figuratively to describe a concrete entity noun

Along the same lines as the
[maSdar]{.trn2}→adjectival noun
we sometimes see a [maSdar]{.trn2} used 
figuratively to describe a concrete entity noun.
For example:

(@ex000402) [ترتع ما رتعت حتى إذا ادّكرت فإنما هي إقبال وإدبار]{.ar}
    [[[معاني النحو]{.ar} 1/193](https://shamela.ws/book/17801/192)]{.citex}  
    [[The she-camel] pastures at pleasure until she remembers [her offspring], then she is only (the act of) approaching and withdrawing.]{.trans}
